Next# DQXA asked Italians why they thought the United States had given —
and continues to give — financial aid to Italy. Fifteen per cent said America
sincerely desires to help Italy get back on her feet so that she can maintain
herself. Forty eight per cent said it was because America wants to stop Italy
from going Communist, thirty two per cent said America wants to have friends in
Italy so as to have Italy for an ally In the event of war with Russia. And 19
per cent said the United States was giving aid In order to take possession of
Italian markets. You will note that these percentages exceed one hundred, for
some persons polled gave more than one answer.
At a time when ratification of the European array treaty is a lively issue
in Italian politics, DOXAfs next question was timely and Interesting. It listed
several possible ways to prevent the outbreak of a new war, and asked Italians
to choose the one they thought best.
Th© biggest single group — 37 per cent of those interviewed — answered
that they did not know. The second biggest group — 34 per cent — said the
beat way to prevent war vac by stepping up the rearmament of western Europe.
Fourteen per cent said the best way to begin the disarmament of western
Eurooej three per cent said it was best to leave western European armament at
its present level. Twelve per emit answered, with regard to this question about
the best way to prevent a new war* “One can do nothing#*
Finally, DOXA singled out the 34 par cent who said the best way to prevent
*far was by Increasing the rearmament of western Europe and asked i Is It desir¬
able that America aid Italy to rearm?* ninety two per cent said yes and four
per cent said no.
As I*m sure the officials of the DQXA polling agency would concede, we
should be careful not to read too much into those results of the poll about
Italian attitudes toward America and Americans. But I think these two general
conclusions might be justified#
First, there is no substantial anti-American feeling in Italy $ on the con¬
trary# a majority of Italians seems to have more sympathy and affection for
Americans than for their neighbors of western Europe.
And second, Americans as individuals are more popular with Italians than
American policies, as a general rule.
Both of these points confirm strong hunches that I reported In a previous
Letter from Italy. Friends told ai© before I came last year that I might find a
rising tide of anti-Americanism. But as I said previously, if such feeling
exists I can*t find it — in Rome or anywhere else. And the DOXA poll, with its
evidence that many Italians think of Americans as generous, practical and in¬
dustrious# confirms my feeling that if anti-Americanism exists it Is confined to
a small minority. In fact# these DOXA reports tend to confirm something Italian
friends have been telling me for a long time4
That the weakest and most ineffective part of the Communist propaganda
effort in Italy Is its anti-Araerlean aspect.
on the other hand, many Italians who like Americans are somewhat distrust¬
ful of some aspects of American foreign policy. Recall for a moment the 69 per
cent in the DOXA poll who said the statement that America aims to dominate the
world was either true or partly true.
.And I would like to add one more observation only indirectly related to
this particular DOXA poll*
